componenttext: Martin, a longer-term question for you. What do you believe is the margin potential for your portfolio after you get through all the restructuring, after the sales model conversions, along with the smaller exposure to frac? And let's say the market delivers a modest kind of middle of the road recovery in upstream spending over the next few years. What do you think is the normalized margin level that is reasonably achievable for your mix of businesses?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question. I think it's one you're going to have to wait until we see the market settle out a bit more, we see our business settle out a bit more. Don't forget, 6 months ago we were in a very different state. We've moved extremely fast, fixed
componenttext: It's a great question. I think it's one you're going to have to wait until we see the market settle out a bit more, we see our business settle out a bit more. Don't forget, 6 months ago we were in a very different state. We've moved extremely fast, fixed a lot of things. We have more to do. Kimberly highlighted the -- some of the manufacturing strategy. I'm not prepared yet to put a number out there as to a normalized rate. But we feel -- we've got a lot of smiles on our faces on this side of the fence. We feel really good about where our business is going. I'm just going to leave it at that right now, Scott.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if I could ask a follow-up. Do you think it's unreasonable to assume that you can do better than the low teens margins you achieved last cycle?
componenttext: Well, if I could ask a follow-up. Do you think it's unreasonable to assume that you can do better than the low teens margins you achieved last cycle?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tell me what oil prices are and gas prices and -- look, I'm not trying to avoid your question. I think as we get further through this process in our business and we get our portfolio where we want it to be, we still have some moving pieces. We still have
componenttext: Tell me what oil prices are and gas prices and -- look, I'm not trying to avoid your question. I think as we get further through this process in our business and we get our portfolio where we want it to be, we still have some moving pieces. We still have -- putting some meat on the bones with regards to our new channels. When we have that all sorted out, I think we'll be prepared to put some numbers out there for you.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Boyd with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Boyd with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry to keep following up on the baseline EBITDA run rate but I want to give it one more shot. When I fully adjust the numbers, I get to about $224 million in EBITDA adjusted for 3Q. 4Q, presumably we're going to see another $10 million benefit since hal
componenttext: Sorry to keep following up on the baseline EBITDA run rate but I want to give it one more shot. When I fully adjust the numbers, I get to about $224 million in EBITDA adjusted for 3Q. 4Q, presumably we're going to see another $10 million benefit since half the $20 million benefit is D&A. So we have a $234 million run rate going into 4Q. So I want to confirm that that's correct. And then, as I think about seasonality in 1Q '17, presumably since you're not seeing the uptick in 4Q, there shouldn't be much of a seasonality impact in 1Q. Is that a fair way to think about it?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- and if it's helpful, later on you can get offline with Alondra if you really want to get into the details. But the way -- if you're looking at it right now, $269 million was your starting point. You've got $45 million of non-reoccurring items. That
componenttext: So -- and if it's helpful, later on you can get offline with Alondra if you really want to get into the details. But the way -- if you're looking at it right now, $269 million was your starting point. You've got $45 million of non-reoccurring items. That takes you to $224 million. Then if you take $20 million of the cost savings, so then you end up at $244 million, right, if you're doing math. And then, of course, you need to take into account what happens with activity in Q4, which -- that's obviously not something that we know the answer to yet.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. Sorry. And then as I think about your AutoTrak and the market share that you're gaining, one of your other competitors mentioned that they're sold out. Is this something that you can use to pull through other products and services or bundle to
componenttext: Okay, yes. Sorry. And then as I think about your AutoTrak and the market share that you're gaining, one of your other competitors mentioned that they're sold out. Is this something that you can use to pull through other products and services or bundle to gain market share beyond just AutoTrak?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, Dan. And we're about sold out as well. As to a pull-along, there's not as much of that going on in North America. Very few, very, very few, I wouldn't even call them bids, transactional activity is in any kind of combined state. But
componenttext:
It's a good question, Dan. And we're about sold out as well. As to a pull-along, there's not as much of that going on in North America. Very few, very, very few, I wouldn't even call them bids, transactional activity is in any kind of combined state. But given the performance of our systems and the leverage that we have, and particularly as it starts to tighten up, I think you'll see more and more around completions being pulled through. 
But we remain very focused on execution. And I think our share position is going to just continue to grow, one, because of performance; and two, which I think is a bit lost on the marketplace, is where these wells are going, and you cannot drill them with a motor. Your torque and drag will just tear you up. So -- and we have the only rotary steerable that has the ability to gently push off and -- versus an on/off type of switch, which creates a pretty torturous well path. Which is no big deal if you've got a 10,000-foot lateral. But as we approach 20,000-foot laterals, you've got to have really a smooth environment. So yes, I think we will be pulling through more services as this market evolves.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Jim Wicklund with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our last question comes from Jim Wicklund with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: International, Martin, historically -- and you and I have been doing this a while, internationally usually takes about 6 to 12 months to begin to recover after the U.S. But this time, with deepwater, the rising tide not lifting all boats and you're still
componenttext: International, Martin, historically -- and you and I have been doing this a while, internationally usually takes about 6 to 12 months to begin to recover after the U.S. But this time, with deepwater, the rising tide not lifting all boats and you're still talking about activity and pricing pressure in the international, can you give us what your expectation is of how long the recovery is going to be generally in international following the domestic recovery we've already seen?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a very -- and you're right, Jim. We've been in this a long time. And I think it's a little different. North America's activity bump is because of a significant amount of the deflation that's come off of our backs and our competitors' ba
componenttext:
Well, I think it's a very -- and you're right, Jim. We've been in this a long time. And I think it's a little different. North America's activity bump is because of a significant amount of the deflation that's come off of our backs and our competitors' backs. That isn't going to be there forever. And as we were just talking to Dan around some of the technology, we're getting tapped out in North America. 
And so that is a -- that's a response in the market because of our costs coming down. So it's not that the fundamentals of, I think, our customer community being able to really make money at $50 oil. It's because we're giving up too much of the economic rent. And that's going to go away eventually. 
Internationally, I hate to say this, Jim, if we don't see $55 oil in the North Sea, it's not coming back. And I think we need $65 in West Africa. Russia is staying steady, I think for reasons that is really around production-level mandates versus pure economics. Parts of the Caspian and so forth are flat to trending down. 
Now Middle East is -- definitely continues to be a bright spot. And it gets back to low-cost producer wins in this market. So substantial, I think -- I don't think I'm exaggerating when I say substantial opportunity in Kuwait, Saudi, the United Arab Emirates and so forth, Oman. 
But besides that, if we don't get a lift in oil prices that's durable beyond just a few days or weeks, I don't see the rest of the world coming back in any meaningful way.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's -- we'll pray for higher oil prices. And my follow-up, if I could. Russia, one of the larger companies mentioned it in glowing terms a number of times. Can you talk about your exposure in Russia and how big of a market that could be for your
componenttext: Okay. That's -- we'll pray for higher oil prices. And my follow-up, if I could. Russia, one of the larger companies mentioned it in glowing terms a number of times. Can you talk about your exposure in Russia and how big of a market that could be for your more direct sales group? I know in Saudi they're pushing for 70% and all, but Russia is a different animal. Can you talk about your potential in Russia and your activity in Russia?

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Year-on-year, we picked up over 100 drilling rigs in Russia. Now obviously our state of play last year was a bit bobbled and cumbersome given the situation we were in. So they've hit the market hard, and the customers have responded. Again, technology is
componenttext:
Year-on-year, we picked up over 100 drilling rigs in Russia. Now obviously our state of play last year was a bit bobbled and cumbersome given the situation we were in. So they've hit the market hard, and the customers have responded. Again, technology is playing a role. 
In terms of overall size, I envision that we'll have a very large business in Russia, but it'll be somewhat of a hybrid. They'll be leveraging the local content initiatives that are taking place. And again, the trade secrets and the model that we'll have around these new channels will facilitate that growth. 
On the other hand, in parts of Western Siberia, the technology demands are still high. And that goes to the fact that, as I said, we've picked up 100 drilling rigs in Russia just in the last 8 months. So I don't want to quantify for you at this stage, but it's going to be a bigger part of our Eastern Hemisphere business, I'm pretty confident of.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will now turn the call back to Martin Craighead for closing remarks.
componenttext: I will now turn the call back to Martin Craighead for closing remarks.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Abigail. So let me just -- let me thank all of you for joining us, and let me wrap up with 3 points. First, there continue to be some challenging conditions, and volatility and uncertainty remain. But there is some growing optimism that the cond
componenttext:
Thanks, Abigail. So let me just -- let me thank all of you for joining us, and let me wrap up with 3 points. 
First, there continue to be some challenging conditions, and volatility and uncertainty remain. But there is some growing optimism that the conditions needed for a sustained recovery are closer at hand than they seemed to be just a few months ago. The strong progress that we made on all 3 components of our plan I want to remind you of, from costs and controls to commercial strategy and capital structure. And finally, we achieved stronger performance in the third quarter, largely due to accelerated execution on cost reductions and efforts to fortify our core business and top line results. This is aligned with our focus to achieve profitable growth and improved returns on capital for Baker Hughes. 
Again, I want to thank you all for joining us, and have a good rest of your day.

headline: Baker Hughes Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating in today's conference. This concludes the program, and you may all disconnect. Everyone, have a great day.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating in today's conference. This concludes the program, and you may all disconnect. Everyone, have a great day.
